    Produce a Detection Error Tradeoff (DET) Curve Plot

    mizr_det_plot.Rd

    This produces a Detection Error Tradeoff (DET) Curve following the work of:

    mizr_det_plot(
  df,
  score_col,
  key_col,
  key_values = c(0, 1),
  dec_col = NULL,
  cp_miss = 1,
  cp_fa = 1,
  pp_hkv = 0.5,
  cs_miss = 1,
  cs_fa = 1,
  ps_hkv = 0.9,
  sys_name = ""
)

    Arguments

    df

    the data frame of scores and decisions to produce the DET curve for

    score_col

    the column containing the system scores.

    key_col

    the column of the data frame that contains the key (ground truth)

    key_values

    a two-element vector with (low_key_value, high_key_value), where the high_key_value is interpreted as the target or the positive trait.

    dec_col

    the column containing the system's actual decisions. Set to NULL if there are no decisions provided. Defaults to NULL.

    cp_miss

    the cost of a miss for the primary cost function. Defaults to 1.

    cp_fa

    the cost of a false alarm for the primary cost function. Defaults to 1.

    pp_hkv

    The prior probability of the high_key_value for the primary cost function, which is the prior probability of the target class or positive class. Defaults to 0.5, meaning that with the defaults misses and false alarms are equally weighted.

    cs_miss

    the cost of a miss for the secondary cost function. Defaults to 1.

    cs_fa

    the cost of a false alarm for the secondary cost function. Defaults to 1.

    ps_hkv

    The prior probability of the high_key_value for the secondary cost function, which is the prior probability of the target class or positive class. Defaults to 0.9, meaning that with the defaults misses and false alarms are qually weighted.

    sys_name

    the name of the system. Defaults to "".

    Value

    mizr_plot a plot object

    Details

    Martin, Alvin F., George R. Doddington, Terri Kamm, Mark Ordowski, and Mark A. Przybocki. 1997. “The DET Curve in Assessment of Detection Task Performance.” In Fifth European Conference on Speech Communication and Technology, EUROSPEECH 1997. Rhodes, Greece. http://www.isca-speech.org/archive/eurospeech_1997/e97_1895.html.

    This produces a DET curve for a single system, and has options to support actual decisions in addition to minimum scores, and allows for parameterizable costs. Parameterization is supported both in costs of a miss and false alarm as well as the prior probability of a target, or "high_key_value".

    The DET curve supports two decision cost functions: a primary cost function (p) and a secondary cost function (s). This allows for scenarios such as a forensic and investigative analysis that provides a system's performance according to two cost functions
